title: Hanuman Jayanti: The Birthday of the One Who Never Left
excerpt: Of all the figures in the Hindu tradition, Hanuman is the one most people turn to when they are genuinely afraid. Not for magic, not for miracles ‚Äî but because he is the model of what a human being looks like when they have completely given up the burden of their own ego and replaced it with something so much lighter: love.

body.heading: Born From the Wind, Raised by the Mountain
body.text: Hanuman was born to Anjana ‚Äî a celestial nymph who had taken birth as a monkey due to a curse ‚Äî and to the Wind God Vayu, who was his divine father. He was born on the full moon of Chaitra (the same month as Ram Navami, nine days earlier), and from the very beginning his life was full of impossible feats and corrective humiliations. As an infant, he once leapt toward the rising sun, mistaking it for a ripe fruit. Indra struck him with his thunderbolt and wounded his jaw ‚Äî hence the name 'Hanuman' (han = jaw, man = disfigured). Vayu, enraged, withdrew the breath of life from the universe; all living beings began to suffocate. The gods panicked and showered the unconscious child with boons to appease Vayu: Brahma gave him immunity from weapons, Indra gave him a body harder than thunderbolts, Varuna gave him protection from water, Agni from fire, Surya from heat. Hanuman was born armored by the entire cosmos. And yet he would spend his life as a servant.

body.heading: The Curse That Made Him Human
body.text: Here is the part of Hanuman's story that most devotees know but rarely pause on: Hanuman forgot his own power. As a child he was so mischievous ‚Äî tormenting sages in their ashrams, uprooting trees, disrupting their meditations ‚Äî that the sages finally cursed him: he would forget his abilities until someone reminded him of them. This curse, which looks like a punishment, was actually a transformation. It turned an impossibly powerful being into something more useful ‚Äî into a being who lives in humility, who does not lead with his strength, who works quietly in service rather than spectacularly in exhibition. The entire Sunderkand, the most beloved chapter of the Ramayana, is about the moment Jambavan reminds Hanuman of who he is ‚Äî and Hanuman, remembering, leaps across an ocean. But notice what he does when he lands in Lanka: he searches quietly, in the night, without fanfare. Power that has passed through humility becomes something different ‚Äî it becomes grace.

body.heading: Why Hanuman Is Ram's Greatest Devotee
body.text: When asked about his relationship to Ram, Hanuman once said something that is among the most quoted lines in the devotional tradition: 'When I think of myself as a body, I am your servant. When I think of myself as an individual soul, I am a part of you. When I think of myself as the Atman, I am you.' This is not ordinary devotion. It is a complete philosophical statement of the three levels of spiritual understanding ‚Äî dvaita (duality), vishishtadvaita (qualified non-duality), and advaita (non-duality) ‚Äî delivered not by a scholar in a lecture but by a monkey in a conversation. Hanuman is the model of Bhakti Yoga: the path of love and devotion. He demonstrates that devotion is not weakness. It is the most demanding of all paths ‚Äî it requires the complete dissolution of personal agenda, the willingness to do whatever is asked without resentment, the capacity to remain joyful in service rather than seeking credit. Hanuman is not diminished by serving Ram. He is completed by it.

body.heading: The Chiranjeevi: He Who Did Not Leave
body.text: Hanuman is one of the seven Chiranjeevis ‚Äî the immortals of Hindu tradition ‚Äî and the tradition holds that he is still present on earth, anywhere the Ramayana is being recited. He requested this boon from Ram himself: to remain on earth as long as Ram's name is spoken. The implications of this are felt in temples and homes across the country. When a Ram Katha is performed, a seat is always left empty for Hanuman. When the Sunderkand is recited, devotees feel his presence not as superstition but as something closer to certainty ‚Äî the room changes, the air changes. Whether one takes this literally or symbolically, the meaning is the same: the quality of consciousness that Hanuman represents ‚Äî alert, selfless, devotion-filled, fearless ‚Äî is always available to us. It does not require a specific time or place. It requires only a specific quality of heart.

body.heading: Hanuman Jayanti: How to Celebrate
body.text: Hanuman Jayanti is observed on the full moon of Chaitra, which overlaps with Ram Navami in some regional traditions and falls separately in others. The observance typically involves a fast broken after sunset, a visit to the Hanuman temple (Tuesdays and Saturdays being Hanuman's sacred days), the application of sindoor (vermilion) to the Hanuman idol ‚Äî because Sita's sindoor represents her devotion to Ram, and Hanuman, hearing this, smeared his entire body with sindoor to show his love ‚Äî and the recitation of the Hanuman Chalisa or the Sunderkand. At home, a simple lamp lit before Hanuman's image, with a sincere recitation of the Chalisa, is considered one of the most powerful practices in the tradition for courage, clarity, and protection. The Chalisa's forty verses are not a recitation to be rushed. They are a mirror. Each verse, if read slowly, shows you something Hanuman knew ‚Äî and invites you to remember it too.
